questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a large adrenal mass discovered incidentally on imaging. The tumor measures 12 cm and shows irregular borders with central necrosis. She exhibits symptoms of Cushing syndrome. What is the most likely diagnosis for this adrenal mass?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Adrenocortical Carcinoma

 

Explanation:

Adrenocortical Carcinoma:

  • Characterized by large tumor size (typically >9 cm), irregular borders, and the presence of central necrosis, which matches the clinical scenario.
  • Adrenocortical carcinoma often presents with hormone overproduction and significant local invasion or metastases.
  • Common presentations include Cushing syndrome (M/C) and virilization.
  • Adrenocortical tumor arises from the retroperitoneum.
  • Whenever there is a retroperitoneal mass or pathology involved, the IOC is CECT.
  • CT shows a heterogeneous mass with irregular borders, central necrosis, and invasion of adjacent structures.
  • Possible metastases to lymph nodes, liver, and lungs.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for surgery in an asymptomatic patient with primary hyperparathyroidism?

choices.text: Serum calcium level 0.25 mmol/L above the upper limit of normal
DEXA T score of -2.5 at the lumbar spine

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Age >60 years

 

Explanation:  

Indications of surgery in an asymptomatic case with primary hyperparathyroidism are:

  • Serum calcium 0.25 mmol/L (1.0 mg/dL) above the upper limit of normal (Option A)
  • Bone mineral density (BMD) by DEXA; T score –2.5 at lumbar spine (Option B), total hip, femoral neck, or distal one-third of radius
  • Vertebral fracture
  • Creatinine clearance <60 mL/min (Option C)
  • 24-hour urinary calcium >10 mmol/dL (>400 mg/day) or increased risk of stone formation by risk analysis
  • Age <50 years (Option D)
  • When medical therapy is not possible

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding olfactory neuroblastoma?

choices.text: Benign tumor arising from the squamous epithelium of the nasal cavity.
Presents as a bilateral mass in the lower nasal cavity.
Causes anosmia and nasal obstruction due to a unilateral polypoidal mass.
Treated with chemotherapy alone, with no surgical excision.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Causes anosmia and nasal obstruction due to a unilateral polypoidal mass.

 

Explanation:

  • It is a rare malignant neoplasm of the sinonasal tract that arises from the olfactory neuroepithelium with neuroblastic differentiation (Option A)
  • Most often present in the superior nasal cavity. (Option B)
  • Olfactory neuroblastoma or esthesioneuroblastoma causes a unilateral nasal obstruction and anosmia as it causes a unilateral polypoidal mass. (Option C)
  • Treatment: Surgical excision followed by radiotherapy (Option D)

questions.text: A mother brought her 2-year-old child as she noticed he is unable to completely open his eyes and that there is a limp in his walk. On examination, there is a mass in the abdomen and miosis and anhidrosis in the eyes. A biopsy confirms neuroblastoma. What would be the laboratory findings in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Raised 24 hr urinary catecholamines.

 

Explanation:

  • Neuroblastoma secretes catecholamines which increases the excretion and hence can be seen raised in the 24 hour urine sample

Laboratory evaluation includes:

  • CBC: thrombocytosis (Option D)
  • 24-hour urinary sample: Raised catecholamines (Option A)
  • Renal function
  • Liver function
  • Electrolytes
  • LDH: high (Option B)
  • CT scan of abdomen & pelvis: calcification and metastasis
  • MRI spine: for Horner’s syndrome or cord compression
  • Skeletal surveys
  • Baseline ECG and echocardiogram
  • Increased Neuron-specific enolase (Option C)
  • Biopsy and histology: Small round pale blue cells, known as Homer-Wright pseudorosettes, are seen.

questions.text: A child of 2 years is brought to the hospital with an abdominal mass that has grown from the right to the center of the abdomen for a few months. The child has urinary symptoms and bluish-purple discoloration around the eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Neuroblastoma

 

Explanation:

Abdominal mass with urinary symptoms and bluish-purple discoloration around the eyes (raccoon eyes) point towards the diagnosis of neuroblastoma.

  • Neuroblastomas arise from the sympathetic nervous system (from neural crest cells).
  • The most common site of neuroblastoma is in the retroperitoneum, with adrenals being the most common source.
  • The other sites where neuroblastoma can be found are in the mediastinum, neck, and pelvis.
  • Found in children of <4 years.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient is diagnosed with malignant pheochromocytoma after presenting with persistent hypertension and elevated plasma metanephrines. Imaging reveals metastasis to various sites. Which of the following is not a common site for metastasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Brain

 

Explanation:

Brain is not a common site for metastasis in malignant pheochromocytoma.


 

Malignant Pheochromocytoma

Tumors that have undergone metastasis to Lymph-node (or) Distant site (Biochemically same as Pheochromocytoma)

Survival Rate

5-year survival ranges from 20% to 45%.

Criteria of Malignancy

Malignancy is defined by the development of metastases

Common Sites of Metastasis

Axial skeleton, lymph nodes, liver, lung, and kidney. (Option A,C,D)

Diagnosis

  • MIBG & Gallium Dotate is Best for Diagnosis
  • Biopsy & FNAC are avoided in Malignant Pheochromocytoma
  • Confirmed by the presence of metastases in locations where neuroectodermal tissues are not normally found.
  • This is the primary criterion distinguishing malignant pheochromocytomas from benign ones, as histopathologic features alone are not reliable in predicting malignancy.

Histopathologic Criteria

No histopathologic criteria can accurately predict the clinical course of malignancy.

Primary Treatment

Surgical resection, even if not curative, can offer significant palliative benefits by managing mass effects and reducing catecholamine excess.

Response to Radiotherapy/Chemotherapy

Minimal response to radiotherapy and chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman in her 24th week of pregnancy presents with severe headaches, palpitations, and paroxysmal hypertension. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated plasma metanephrines, and imaging confirms the presence of a pheochromocytoma. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?

choices.text: Use phenoxybenzamine and plan laparoscopic adrenalectomy in the second trimester.
Wait until the third trimester, use Labetalol to control BP, and perform a C-section followed by adrenalectomy.
Use calcium channel blockers and plan for surgical resection postpartum.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Use phenoxybenzamine and plan laparoscopic adrenalectomy in the second trimester.

 

Explanation:

  • For pregnant patients diagnosed with pheochromocytoma, it is essential to initiate α-blockade with phenoxybenzamine to control hypertension and reduce catecholamine excess.
  • Laparoscopic adrenalectomy is typically recommended during the second trimester as it minimizes the risks to both the mother and fetus.

Management of Pheochromocytoma

Biochemical Diagnosis

Identify pheochromocytoma using biochemical tests and imaging for localization.

Preoperative Preparation
  • Start with an α-adrenoceptor blocker like phenoxybenzamine.
  • Adjust the dose to 100-160 mg/day to achieve postural hypotension.
  • Add β-blockers if necessary after α-blockade to manage tachycardia.
  • Other regimens include α-blockade with doxazosin or prazosin, with and without β-blockers, calcium channel blockers alone, and using catecholamine synthesis blocker metyrosine in cardiac failure.

Surgery
  • Laparoscopic Adrenalectomy: Preferred for PCC unless tumor >10 cm or malignant signs are present.
  • Open Surgery: Recommended for large tumors or those along the sympathetic chain.

Postoperative Care
  • Monitor for hypovolemia and hypoglycemia for 24 hrs post-surgery.
  • Conduct annual biochemical tests for recurrence.

Malignant Pheochromocytoma
  • Perform surgical excision, possibly with en bloc resection for invasive tumors.
  • Consider adjuvant therapies like radiolabeled MIBG and octreotide.

Pheochromocytoma in Pregnancy
  • First/Second Trimester: Implement α-blockade, then proceed with laparoscopic adrenalectomy.
  • Third Trimester: Plan for an elective C-section followed by adrenalectomy 6 weeks later.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents with a history of paroxysmal hypertension, palpitations, headaches, and sweating. Initial plasma-free metanephrine testing returns positive results. What is the most appropriate next step in the investigation of this patient's condition to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Performing a 24-hour urine collection for metanephrines
Ordering a CT/MRI scan of the abdomen

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Performing a 24-hour urine collection for metanephrines

 

Explanation:

  • Clinical symptoms of paroxysmal hypertension, palpitations, headaches, and sweating in this patient are strongly suggestive of Pheochromocytoma.
  • After a positive plasma-free metanephrine test, the next step is to perform a 24-hour urine collection for metanephrines and catecholamines to confirm the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma.
  • This test has high specificity (up to 99.6%) and helps differentiate pheochromocytoma from other conditions that can cause similar symptoms. It is crucial to confirm the biochemical diagnosis before proceeding with localization imaging.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with episodes of severe headaches, palpitations, and sweating. Imaging reveals a large adrenal mass and biochemical tests confirm elevated plasma metanephrines. Further genetic testing shows a mutation in the SDHB gene. Which of the following genetic syndromes is most likely associated with her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hereditary Paraganglioma-Pheochromocytoma Syndromes (HPPS)

 

Explanation:

  • The presence of an SDHB gene mutation, along with symptoms of severe headaches, palpitations, sweating, imaging showing a large adrenal mass, and elevated plasma metanephrines, is most consistent with Hereditary Paraganglioma-Pheochromocytoma Syndrome (HPPS).
  • Hereditary Paraganglioma-Pheochromocytoma Syndrome (HPPS) encompasses germline mutations in several genes, including SDH subunits.
  • SDHB mutations are particularly noted for their association with high rates of malignant pheochromocytomas and extra-adrenal tumors.
  • These mutations lead to the accumulation of Krebs cycle intermediates, promoting tumorigenesis.
  • Patients with SDHB mutations are at high risk for malignant extra-adrenal (abdominal or thoracic) tumors, making it the most likely syndrome in this clinical scenario.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presents with intermittent episodes of hypertension, headache, and sweating. After conducting a series of tests, the diagnosis points toward an extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma. What is the most common site for an extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Organ of Zuckerkandl

Explanation:

  • The Organ of Zuckerkandl is the m/c site for extra-adrenal pheochromocytomas and sympathetic paragangliomas.
  • It is located near the aortic bifurcation or close to the origin of the inferior mesenteric artery and often serves as a site for these tumors outside the adrenal glands.
  • M/c site of parasympathetic paraganglioma is the carotid body.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with episodic symptoms of severe headache, palpitations, and profuse sweating. His laboratory tests reveal elevated plasma metanephrines, and a CT scan identifies a vascular adrenal mass. Which of the following statements accurately describes the nature of this adrenal mass?

choices.text: Primarily secretes ACTH, causing continuous hypertension.
It intermittently releases catecholamines, leading to episodes of headache, palpitations, and sweating.
Presents with chronic, steady symptoms without significant paroxysms.
Usually non-vascular and causes minimal clinical symptoms.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) It intermittently releases catecholamines, leading to episodes of headache, palpitations, and sweating.

 

Explanation:

  • Pheochromocytomas cause episodic symptoms due to intermittent bursts of catecholamines, Adrenaline and Noradrenaline, classically resulting in paroxysms of headache, palpitations, and sweating, aligning with the patient's presentation.

Pathophysiology of Pheochromocytomas:

  • Catecholamine Production: Tyrosine is converted to dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA) by tyrosine hydroxylase, then to dopamine, norepinephrine, and finally epinephrine, with PNMT (phenylethanolamine-N-methyltransferase) catalyzing the final step. (Option A)
  • Storage: Catecholamines are stored in vesicles and released into circulation.
  • Release: Pheochromocytomas release catecholamines in paroxysmal, continuous, or mixed patterns, leading to persistent hypertension (norepinephrine) or tachyarrhythmias (epinephrine). (Option C)
  • Epinephrine and Norepinephrine bind to adrenoceptors with varying affinities.
  • Pheochromocytomas are highly vascular and are associated with significant clinical symptoms due to the excessive production of catecholamines. (Option D)

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with h/o chronic kidney disease is found to have elevated serum calcium levels. Which of the following actions of parathyroid hormone (PTH) is most directly responsible for increasing serum calcium levels?

choices.text: Inhibition of calcium reabsorption in the kidneys.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Stimulation of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D production.

 

Explanation:

  • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) stimulates the production of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (active vitamin D) in the kidneys, which enhances intestinal calcium absorption, thereby increasing serum calcium levels.

 

  • Role of Parathyroid Glands: Regulate serum calcium levels through parathyroid hormone (PTH).
  • PTH Secretion: Triggered by low calcium or high magnesium levels. Initially cleaved in the liver yielding an active N-terminal fragment, that has a 3-5 minute half-life.
  • PTH Action:
    • Kidneys: Increases serum calcium by increasing resorption from renal tubules (Option A) and by activating 25-hydroxyvitamin D to 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D (active form). (Option B)
    • Bone: Stimulates osteoblasts and osteoclasts to increase bone turnover, thereby increasing serum calcium. (Option D)
    • GI Tract: Enhances calcium absorption through active vitamin D. (Option C)

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman undergoes a routine abdominal CT scan for an unrelated issue. The scan reveals a 2.5 cm mass in the left adrenal gland. The patient has no history of adrenal disorders but reports occasional episodes of sweating and palpitations. Her blood pressure is elevated. Based on these findings, what condition should be primarily ruled out in the diagnostic workup?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Pheochromocytoma

 

Explanation:

  • Pheochromocytoma should be ruled out in patients with adrenal incidentalomas presenting with symptoms such as sweating and palpitations, particularly if the unenhanced CT attenuation is >10 HU.
  • This condition can cause significant cardiovascular complications if left untreated.

Evaluation of incidentaloma:

Imaging
  • All patients with adrenal incidentalomas should be assessed for malignancy based on the size and imaging characteristics of the mass.
  • CT differentiates benign cortical adenoma from adrenal carcinoma or metastasis.

 

FNAC
  • Fine-needle aspiration differentiates adrenal tumors from metastatic tumors.
  • Biopsy is avoided in suspected pheochromocytomas due to the risk of crisis.
  • FNAC is to be done only after ruling out Pheochromocytoma

Hormonal Evaluation

All patients with adrenal incidentalomas should be assessed for subclinical hormonal hyperfunction.

Pheochromocytoma

24-hour urinary fractionated metanephrines, catecholamines, or plasma fractionated metanephrines

Subclinical Cushing Syndrome

Measure dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS) and perform 1 mg overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST)

Primary Aldosteronism

Measure plasma aldosterone and plasma renin activity (if hypertension or hypokalemia is present)

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with elevated serum calcium levels and a neck mass. After further evaluation, the diagnosis of parathyroid carcinoma is confirmed. The patient is scheduled for surgery. What is the standard surgical treatment for this case to minimize the risk of local recurrence?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) En bloc resection

 

Explanation:

  • En-bloc resection involves removing the tumor and any adjacent structures it has invaded as a single mass, which helps reduce the risk of spilling tumor cells and local recurrence.


 

Management of Parathyroid Carcinoma

En-Bloc Resection

(Option B)

Includes removal of adjacent invaded tissues; performed in 12.5% of cases

Resectable Parathyroid Carcinoma (Local or regional recurrence of parathyroid carcinoma)
  • En-bloc resection is standard for initial and recurrent disease, involving the removal of the tumor along with any invaded structures.
  • Lymph Node Dissection: Performed only if lymph node involvement is confirmed. (Option C)
    CDC73/HRPT2 Variant Carriers: Bilateral exploration or selective resection of abnormal glands.
  • Total parathyroidectomy is not favored. (Option D)
  • Metastasis: Spreads locally, invading adjacent structures in the neck such as the thyroid gland and strap muscles.
  • Surgical resection of metastasis for palliation of hypercalcemia
  • Post-op Serum Calcium Monitoring: Essential for managing "hungry bone syndrome".

Medical Therapy for Unresectable Parathyroid Carcinoma (When parathyroid carcinoma is not resectable due to widespread dissemination)
  • Managed with hypercalcemia control and palliative care.
  • Bisphosphonates: Intravenous zoledronic acid or pamidronate. Calcimimetics: Cinacalcet is used if bisphosphonates are ineffective.

It works on the calcium-sensing receptor (CASR) of the parathyroid gland and controls the parathyroid hormone.

  • Denosumab: For hypercalcemia, refractory to bisphosphonates and cinacalcet.

Biotherapy

Emerging therapies include parafibromin inhibitors, telomerase inhibitors, and immune therapies.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman undergoes a total thyroidectomy for the treatment of Graves' disease. Two days postoperatively, she presents with numbness and tingling around her mouth and in her fingers. She also complains of muscle cramps and mild weakness. Laboratory tests reveal decreased serum calcium levels. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms following the surgery?

choices.text: Hypocalcemia due to damage to the parathyroid glands

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hypocalcemia due to damage to the parathyroid glands

 

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms of numbness, tingling, muscle cramps, and decreased serum calcium levels indicate hypocalcemia.
  • The most common cause of hypocalcemia following thyroid surgery is damage to the parathyroid glands or their blood supply.

 

HYPOPARATHYROIDISM

Common Causes:

Thyroid Surgery

Most frequent cause is damage to the parathyroid glands or their blood supply. (Option B)

Risk Factors:

  • Bilateral neck exploration,
  • Extensive central neck dissection,
  • Revision surgery,
  • Thyroidectomy for Graves' disease,
  • Pediatric patients.

Autoimmune Disorders

Autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome type 1 (APS-1).

Genetic Conditions

DiGeorge syndrome, autosomal dominant hypocalcemia.

Radiation Therapy

Radiation to the neck area can damage parathyroid glands.

Medications

Lithium, and some chemotherapeutic agents (Pembrolizumab).

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of tertiary hyperparathyroidism undergoes total parathyroidectomy. Three days later, she presents with carpopedal spasms and numbness around her mouth. Her serum calcium level is 6.9 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hungry bone syndrome

 

Explanation:

Hungry Bone Syndrome (HBS):

  • It is a state of profound hypocalcemia that persists for prolonged periods following parathyroidectomy or after thyroidectomy and can also be seen in metastatic prostate cancer.
  • Pathophysiology: Rapid calcium uptake by bones after removal of excess hormone (PTH).
  • Symptoms:
    • Seizures
    • Tetany
    • Paresthesia
    • Carpopedal spasms
    • Arrhythmias
    • Laryngospasm
  • Management:
    • Oral Supplements: Calcium carbonate or calcium citrate.
    • Indications for IV Calcium: Serum calcium <7.6 mg/dL, symptomatic patients, or EKG changes.
    • IV Calcium: Calcium gluconate (preferred) or calcium chloride.

questions.text: A 57-year-old patient with chronic renal failure is found to have elevated parathyroid hormone levels, but his serum calcium level is in the normal range. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Secondary hyperparathyroidism

 

Explanation:

A raised parathyroid hormone with normal or low serum calcium level points to the diagnosis of secondary hyperparathyroidism.

Secondary hyperparathyroidism (Option C)

Definition

Physiologic response of parathyroid glands to hypocalcemia

Causes
  • Chronic renal failure:
    • ￬ phosphate excretion
    • ￪serum phosphate binds to serum calcium & ￬free serum calcium levels.
    • ￬1-hydroxylase activity in the kidney ➜ ￬ 1,25 (OH)2 vitamin D formation ➜ ￬ intestinal absorption of calcium.
    • This results in increased secretion of parathyroid hormone.
  • Vitamin D deficiency
  • Intestinal calcium malabsorption/ steatorrhoea

Management
  • Phosphate intake should be reduced, and phosphate binders should be used to manage excess phosphate.
  • Vitamin D and calcium supplementation.
  • Parathyroidectomy should be considered if secretion remains abnormal.
  • Patients with Chronic renal failure: High Calcium, low aluminium dialysis bath.


 

   

Causes

Impaired graft function, non-suppressible PTH, slow gland involution, insufficient calcitriol conversion.

Diagnosis

Elevated serum calcium, elevated PTH, reduced phosphate (at least 1 year post-transplant).

Management

Surgical intervention: Mainstay of treatment: Subtotal or total parathyroidectomy with autotransplantation of parathyroid gland.

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady comes to the emergency department with muscle weakness, fatigue, and abdominal pain, and on evaluation, has some memory loss. Her lab reports show elevated serum calcium levels (13mg%), and she is diagnosed with primary hyperparathyroidism. Which of the following is the preferred treatment in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Parathyroidectomy

  •  

Explanation:

  • In severely symptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT), the most preferred mode of management is surgical management.
  • The main modality of treatment is as follows:

questions.text: Which of the following is the most accurate investigation to localize the lesion in a case of primary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sestamibi scan

Explanation:

  • Sestamibi scan is a type of nuclear medicine-based study that is most accurate for parathyroid lesion localization.
  • It is safe and reproducible.
  • It has a sensitivity and specificity similar to ultrasound but may detect glands in ectopic positions better.
  • Sestamibi accumulates in the mitochondria and hence the rates at which it washes out differs as per the number of mitochondria in different tissues.
  • Parathyroid adenoma is rich in oxyphilic cells with a high concentration of mitochondria and hence has a lower washout than the thyroid gland.
  • False positives are rare and the sensitivity and specificity are 79% and 90% respectively.
  • Addition of a thyroid specific radioactive-tracer eliminates the chance of false positives.

questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with a fracture of the radius. She is found to have some mild memory impairment on questioning and her X-ray shows osteoporosis. On further evaluation, her serum calcium levels are elevated. Which of the following is not a common manifestation of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Neck mass

Explanation:

  • The diagnosis here points to primary hyperparathyroidism.
  • A neck mass is an uncommon finding in cases of hyperparathyroidism.
  • The abnormality in the parathyroid gland leads to the increased secretion of parathyroid hormone.

 

Causes of primary hyperparathyroidism :

  • The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is a solitary parathyroid adenoma ( most common on the inferior lobe of the right parathyroid).

    Manifestations of PHPT:

    System

    Manifestations

    Reason

    Renal system

    (stones)

    • Hypercalciuria
    • Nephrocalcinosis
    • Nephrolithiasis (Option A)
    • Polydipsia, polyuria, nocturia
    • Excretion of excess serum calcium
    • Calcium deposition in renal parenchyma
    • Precipitation of calcium with phosphate or oxalate
    • Inhibition of ADH due to ￪ serum calcium.

    Skeletal system
    • Osteoporosis
    • Subperiosteal resorption(radial aspect)
    • Tufting of distal phalanx
    • Brown tumor/ osteitis fibrosa cystica (OptionD)

     
    • Salt and pepper skull (Option B)

     
    • Chondrocalcinosis
    • Pseudo gout
    • Joint pain
    • Calcium resorption
    • Deposition of hemosiderin in the lesion.

    Abdomen

    (abdominal groans)
    • Nausea
    • Vomiting
    • Constipation
    • Peptic ulcer disease: abdominal groans
    • Inhibitory effect of hypercalcemia on gastrointestinal (GI) smooth muscle contraction.
    • Spasm of sphincters
    • Increased gastrin

    CNS

    (psychiatric moans)

    • Anxiety
    • Depression

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with recurrent kidney stones. Lab tests showed elevated calcium and parathyroid hormone levels. Imaging reveals pituitary adenoma and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors. Her father had similar issues. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Wermer syndrome

 

Explanation:

  • MEN 1 syndrome presents with Parathyroid tumors (Hyperparathyroidism and hypercalcemia), pituitary adenoma, and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors.
  • Wermer syndrome is also known as Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1 (MEN 1)

MEN 1/ Wermer Syndrome:

  • Autosomal dominant.
  • Mutation of the MEN-1 gene, located on chromosome 11, affects tumor suppressor protein menin.
  • Involves:
    • Parathyroid tumors
    • Pituitary tumors
    • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors
